current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To restore an opportunity for economic development by the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe on terms that 
	      are equal and fair, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Alabama-Coushatta Tribe of Texas 
Equal and Fair Opportunity Settlement Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alabama-Coushatta Tribe of Texas Equal and Fair Opportunity Settlement Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
Congress finds that—

the United States, pursuant to Federal law and in accordance with several Federal court decisions,
			 has affirmed  the rights of tribes, including the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe,
			 to free and undisturbed  use and occupancy of the aboriginal land of the
			 tribes, including the right  to
			 compensation when those rights are violated;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Court of Federal Claims

text.#text:
in June 2000, in the case entitled Alabama-Coushatta Tribe of Texas v. U.S. (Fed. Cl. Jun 19, 2000)
			 (No. 3–83), the

that failure would have consituted a claim eligible to be heard by the Indian Claims Commission
			 established by the first section of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (November 1, 1983), it was the sense of the

that the Federal Government should pay full
			 monetary
			 compensation to the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe for the 2,850,028 acres of
			 aboriginal land
			 illegally occupied by non-Indian settlers after 1845;

text.#text: as described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
awarded $270,600,000 as the jointly stipulated amount of economic
			 damages to be recovered by the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe from the United
			 States; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
United States Court of Federal
			 Claims

text.#text: in October 2002, the

this Act represents a good faith effort on the part of Congress to provide the Alabama-Coushatta
			 Tribe with the compensation that the United States Court of Claims has
			 determined is owed to the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe.
The purposes of this Act are—

to restore an economic development opportunity to the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe on terms that are
			 equal and fair; and

to protect the Federal Government and taxpayers from liability
			 arising out of or relating to claims on the aboriginal land.

Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the United States and the
			 Alabama-Coushatta Tribe shall execute and file in each applicable court a
			 motion for dismissal of any pending claim arising out of or relating to
			 the aboriginal land or an interest in the aboriginal land.

header.#text: Approval of invalid transfers; extinguishment of claims and aboriginal title

text.#text:
Any claim (including any claim for damages for trespass or for use and occupancy) by, or on behalf
			 of, the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe against the United States or the State of
			 Texas for the loss of aboriginal title shall be deemed to be extinguished.
Nothing in this subsection—

affects or limits any personal claim (except for a Federal common law fraud claim) of an individual
			 Indian that is pursued under any law of general applicability that
			 protects non-Indians and Indians; or

alters the status of land held in trust by the United States on behalf of the Alabama-Coushatta
			 Tribe.
